Literature Review: Maternal mortality remains a critical public health concern in the United States, with rates significantly higher than those observed in other developed nations. This literature review examines the trends, disparities, and potential prevention strategies related to maternal mortality in the United States.The United States has experienced a concerning increase in maternal mortality rates over the past few decades, despite advancements in medical care and technology. According to a study by MacDorman et al. (2016), the maternal mortality rate in the United States increased from 18.8 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2000 to 23.8 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2014. This trend stands in stark contrast to the declining rates observed in other high-income countries, highlighting the urgent need for targeted interventions and policy changes.One of the most striking aspects of maternal mortality in the United States is the significant disparities observed across various demographic groups. Racial and ethnic disparities are particularly pronounced, with Black women facing a disproportionately higher risk of pregnancy-related death compared to their white counterparts. Howell (2018) reported that Black women are three to four times more likely to die from pregnancy-related complications than white women, even after controlling for factors such as education and socioeconomic status. These disparities underscore the complex interplay of social determinants of health, systemic racism, and access to quality healthcare in shaping maternal health outcomes.Geographic disparities also play a crucial role in maternal mortality rates across the United States. Moaddab et al. (2018) found that maternal mortality rates varied significantly between states, with some southern states experiencing rates more than double the national average. Rural areas, in particular, face unique challenges in providing adequate maternal healthcare, including limited access to specialized obstetric care and longer travel distances to healthcare facilities.The underlying causes of maternal mortality in the United States have shifted over time, reflecting changes in population health and healthcare practices. Creanga et al. (2015) observed a relative increase in mortality resulting from cardiovascular diseases and other preexisting medical conditions. This shift highlights the importance of addressing chronic health conditions and risk factors before and during pregnancy to improve maternal health outcomes.Preconception health and counseling have emerged as critical components in reducing maternal mortality. Robbins et al. (2014) emphasized the importance of identifying and managing preexisting health conditions in women of reproductive age before pregnancy occurs. By addressing risk factors such as obesity, hypertension, and diabetes prior to conception, healthcare providers can potentially mitigate the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes and maternal mortality.The postpartum period has been identified as a crucial time for intervention in maternal health. Spelke and Werner (2018) noted that a significant proportion of pregnancy-related deaths occur in the weeks and months following delivery. They advocated for extended postpartum care and follow-up, including screening for mental health issues and chronic conditions that may have been exacerbated by pregnancy.Improving access to quality healthcare throughout the reproductive lifespan is essential in addressing maternal mortality. Petersen et al. (2019) highlighted the importance of continuity of care, suggesting that better integration of primary care, obstetric care, and specialty services could help identify and manage risk factors more effectively. They also emphasized the need for culturally competent care to address the disparities faced by minority populations.The role of social determinants of health in maternal mortality cannot be overstated. Crear-Perry et al. (2021) argued that addressing systemic racism and socioeconomic inequalities is crucial in reducing maternal mortality rates, particularly among Black and indigenous women. They called for policy interventions that address social and economic factors, such as housing, education, and employment, which significantly impact maternal health outcomes.Efforts to improve data collection and surveillance of maternal deaths have been crucial in understanding and addressing the maternal mortality crisis. Main et al. (2015) described the implementation of maternal mortality review committees across the United States, which have been instrumental in identifying preventable factors contributing to maternal deaths and developing targeted interventions.In conclusion, addressing maternal mortality in the United States requires a multifaceted approach that encompasses preconception health, quality prenatal care, improved postpartum follow-up, and efforts to address systemic inequalities. By focusing on these areas and implementing evidence-based interventions, there is potential to reverse the troubling trends in maternal mortality and improve maternal health outcomes for all women in the United States.
